title: Why do many students hate school? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yeah, I know there are 100+ answers and I’m probably not adding anything too new, but I keep seeing this one pop up in my feed and I have a variety of perspectives on it. Currently, I love school. Previously, I hated school. Before that, I was ambivalent. Before that, I hated it, and before that I liked it, mostly. I’ve seen a number of current students reflecting some of my thoughts at the time, but at 28 I have a more evolved perspective, and can more easily figure out what the “real” problem I had was, rather than the somewhat played out “when will I use…” type of issues. I have a much more nuanced opinion on that issue, but that’s probably appropriate for a different answer. I had different reasons for loving or hating school throughout time, and the fun thing about being an adult is that it’s harder to dismiss my answer due to ageism. Even more fun, I teach. So its even harder to dismiss. Elementary school: I generally liked it since I could see my friends, make arts and crafts, and learn things. I felt trapped by homework often, and some problems that seem small from an adult perspective were huge, such as my handwriting. My handwriting has always been awful, but it was a source of great distress in elementary school as we got a letter grade for it. I would regularly get B-’s and C’s. There’s literally no perspective for an elementary schooler that gets in trouble because of a C in Handwriting, no way to know that your problem isn’t actually the end of the world. I imagine a lot of elementary schoolers begin to get poisoned on school in this way, because without actual experience and points of reference, and with a society that says “you are your letter grades,” how can you not? Its also a bit early in development to start questioning things to a really deep level, and behave in a way that isn’t merely reactive to your environment. By 5th grade though, I hated school. Not just because of the homework or seemingly nonsensical structures forced on us, but because I was actively bullied by both students and my teacher. I have written about this in other answers, but the school environment is toxic to a lot of students, so any benefit you might be getting by being there is overridden by its sheer toxicity. School becomes synonymous with pain. Middle school: I was overall ambivalent toward school in middle school. It was a tough transition period but I was being challenged academically, had a friend group, and good teachers so it was better overall. I find it hard to claim I “hated school” in middle school so it’s a good contrast. I also had enough free time to pursue some hobbies and have fun. If school has supportive teachers, a good friend/support group, time to pursue their own interests, and classes that generally match developmental levels, it is a good experience. However, that combination is a rare unicorn. “Why do many students hate school?” They don’t have this winning combination. High school: I hated high school so much. There wasn’t a whole lot redeemable about it, except maybe marching band. Reasons: ~I slept through 1–2 classes everyday after getting up at 530 to be sitting in class by 715. In middle school, I slept on the bus, because middle school started later than high school and we dropped the high schoolers off before driving to the middle school. I usually tried to grab a window seat and passed out on my backpack. High school? Nope, I slept through first or second period instead. Every couple weeks I would come home from school pass out uncontrollably on my bed until about dinner, when I would eat and then go to bed early. I tried to go to bed earlier but couldn’t fall asleep until after midnight no matter what I did, even if I just laid in bed and stared at the ceiling, or tried to meditate. My problems with this were generally belittled as me not trying hard enough. My senior year I got “late arrival” by scheduling study hall first period and having my parents fill out a permission slip to let me drive myself in late (this is a privilege for seniors only that was offered by the school, I wasn’t some special case). I got a 4.0 my senior year. This is not a coincidence. Sometimes I imagine what my life would have been like in high school if I had late arrival starting freshman year. It’s depressing. ~Utter powerlessness and grappling with double standards. This is the root of most of the answers. This ties into helicopter parenting, having a schedule handed to you, being told what to do, having your questions and concerns belittled because of your age, being told “you think you know everything because you are a teenager” when you’re asking questions so you can understand what you know you don’t understand, being restrained by nonsensical dress codes, being told that every single quiz will make or break your chances at college, questioning forbidden topics such as religion and societal mores, being told to stop being lazy and get a job in an economically depressed area, but being told you can’t even apply for certain kinds of jobs or in certain towns that have more opportunities, and so on. A lot of other answer-ers had similar problems, and it all boils down to the sheer powerlessness of being old enough to begin to reason and understand and running headlong into a huge gilded cage built by “adults”. A gilded cage is still a cage. ~An economically poor district. This one was especially bad in my area. We were not a rich district, because that’s what happens when your school budgets are based on property taxes in an economically depressed region. The coal dried up, jobs got shipped overseas in the 90s, and the area still hasn’t recovered. I graduated before the 2008 recession, thank goodness, but they were constantly trying to pass levies so the school districts could afford to run. These measures almost always got voted down because no one could afford to pay more for schools. As a result, our best school was… mediocre at best. Understaffed and undersupplied were the least of our problems. We were also stricken with government mandates we couldn’t afford to implement, and it got worse after No Child Left Behind. I had a few teachers with ridiculous job security and no filter. I learned more about educational politics listening to them rant about the bullshit that went on behind the scenes… but ultimately there can be systemic reasons to hate school. How could anyone love attending an underfunded, overcrowded district?? ~Lack of support for TAG (talented and gifted) students coupled with overcrowding and greater higher reasoning skills so you fully understand that you’re being cheated. I remember an assignment from elementary school that described the proper “roles” of the students in class. We were a mixed class with everyone from LD-TAG. The role of the average student was to listen to the teachers, take notes, and do a(n average) job. The role of the LD students was to, well, not break anything. Just at least try, please. The role of the advanced students was to help everyone catch up to the “average” level. This educational philosophy was present in almost all of my mixed-level classes. As an advanced student, I was all but ignored by a the vast majority of my teachers because I “wasn’t a problem” and “didn’t need help”. Instead I got to sit there bored, waiting for everyone to catch up, or was told to “teach my peers”. In kid language, “teach your peers” doesn’t mean tutoring them. It means handing them your answer sheet while they copy it. In elementary school, this philosophy was merely irritating. By high school, I understood what was going on and refused to participate, focusing on my own education instead by reading nonfiction during study time. I would get in trouble for going ahead. I would get in trouble for trying to learn above the level expected in class. I would get in trouble for doodling because I just couldn’t take sitting there anymore. It didn’t matter what I did or how good of a student I was, I was in trouble. In more advanced classes, things were a little better, but because my school district was poor, we didn’t have a whole lot of advanced offerings and we had a lot of overcrowding. Even in the advanced classes this pattern sometimes cropped up, depending on the teacher. When you’re getting in trouble for being a good student and learning more than is in the curriculum, how is any student expected to enjoy school???? ~Inability to motivate studentsMy teachers and parents were trying to motivate me to do better. They did this through threats and lectures. “You have a B in math, I thought you wanted to be an astronaut? If you want to do any STEM thing you have to be getting all As in math all the time or you can’t do it, ever. Get your grades up. Science and math go hand in hand.”Guess what I did? Gave up my dreams in STEM at the ripe old age of … 12? This is the kind of “motivation” most teachers and parents use, and it serves only to poison the well for the students. Want them to hate education? Because that’s what you’re doing… I renewed my real interest in STEM around 26. Not “too late” but in SPITE OF school, teachers, and my parents, not because of them. I am lucky. ~Doesn’t match your study / learning style. Doesn’t help you learn your study / learning style. Doesn’t care.Also in elementary school we did an assignment called ‘learning styles’. According to the little quiz I took I was primarily a kinesthetic learner with secondary visual. There’s a bit of controversy about learning styles, but now that I’m #@$%ing 28 and have had time and maturity to figure out how studying works for someone who does fit a more kinesthetic profile I can firmly state that the school districts let down everyone who has a propensity towards kinesthetic learning. In our learning styles unit I was literally told that the way a kinesthetic learner might learn best is by doing projects like “making a diorama”. I could go on for a whole answer length about how school doesn’t actually teach you study skills but I’ll save that rant for a question more directly about study skills. Needless to say, there’s no support structure in place for someone who can’t watch a lecture, take notes, and do busywork-homework. On top of this good luck if you’re ADHD / have another learning disability that you can mask through high performance but that’s another answer. Things are getting better for girls with ADHD now though as research is coming out showing that a lot of us got missed because they were comparing us with the kinds of hyperactive symptoms in boys. A lot of my hatred of school came from the entire system failing me, biologically, telling me that because I wasn’t jumping out of my chair, climbing things, and blurting answers I must not have a problem and need to “try harder”. And that’s before the depression and anxiety. College: Loved it. Most of the problems of high school are gone, or at least they were for me. I went to a college that was a good fit for me with a major that was a good fit. A lot of my education was a bit more trade-based so I got to take more of what I liked and less of what I didn’t. The people I saw hating college weren’t ready for it right out of high school, or went to a college that wasn’t a good fit. “Grad School”: right now I’m in an odd place where I’m taking grad classes but am not enrolled in a program. I’m undergoing a bit of a major switch, so I have to do a lot of work before I can get into the program for real. Once again a lot of the people who hate it are in a bad fit situation. They need a different school, a different advisor, a different major. At this level, its so optional that if you don’t love it, get OUT. K-12 doesn’t have that option. You can’t just enroll in a different school. You can’t just drop out and get a job with the Bachelors’ or Masters’ you already have. You can’t change majors. Also because it’s an Ivy, I also see an alarming subset of undergrads that are still under their parents’ boots. Some of the legacy kids didn’t really choose to come here, they were told by their parents that they were coming here because it’s a family tradition. Some were forced into becoming study machines in their teenage years in order to apply to Ivies, and are just following steps A->B->C because its what they were told they had to do “for success”. Some of them are still pursuing their parents’ dreams rather than their own. Contrast that to most of my classmates in undergrad (myself included) who had to fight their parents to even be allowed to attend. I don’t know how anyone who lacks agency while being a legal adult could have any positive feelings toward school, even as an undergrad when you’re supposed to be truly discovering yourself. (Obviously, for the inevitable commenter, this isn’t the whole undergrad population, that’s why I said “subset”. Also obviously, for the inevitable Ivy league undergrad commenter, you’re not going to be able to recognize this agency-less behavior until after you’ve been out off the academic escalator for a few years. In fact, I guarantee at least one of your “overachiever” peers is displaying it. It comes from overachieving without deeply asking “why” and just because your token buddy can get an A in philosophy 101 doesn’t mean they’re self-examined.) Anyway if you made it down here, thanks for putting up with the whole answer, this is one of those topics I could write a book about, and held back considerably while crafting this answer. If you’re still in K-12 prison, keep your chin up. I’m rooting for you.

Ooh boy… where do I begin? I guess we can start with: they hear our pleas and complaints but they always say something like, “your just lazy” or “your not trying hard enough” or “maybe it just isn’t your thing (even though they continue to relentlessly pound the supposed square pig in the round hole.)” or “your a failure” or “your just a whiny teenager with hormonal imbalances who just wants something to complain about.” If we try to speak up about how our educational system is a disfunctional pile of crap, they dismiss us. We can’t change the way the school works! That means I’m trapped! Stuck! Imprisoned in a system that confines me and tortures me and despite my desperate pleas for mercy, the gears of tyrant and oppression march on! I’m helpless! There’s nothing I can do to change this piece of crap! I speak up for myself and I’m sure for others as well, but to no avail! It drives me past the bounds of sanity that I am trapped in a system that seems to actively work against me, claiming its pushing me forward! I’m sick of that Bs! (Excuse me there, I don’t usually curse but sometimes you have to emphasize your points a bit!) a good analogy for the educational systems way of “preparing you for the real world” is throwing you, unarmed, in a pit of hungry wolves in an attempt to teach you how to defend yourself from a person. It’s rediculous! Retarded! And nothing short of stupid. Ok I’m sure you’ve heard me rant about that long enough that you get the picture. We have no freedom. You scoff at how immature and exaggerated it is when someone compares school to prison but, trust me, they aren’t wrong. Classroom: corrective class program thing/jail cell Lunch: honestly, their isn’t much difference here. Just look at the food! Detention: solitary confinement Expulsion: the needle/electric chair Seriously! You’re locked in a room in a locked building. You are expected to stay there, do meaningless work. Your punished for even speaking. Punished for questioning things. Your told when to speak, when to move, when to pee! “Noncompliance” is a sin worthy of capital punishment. Expected to trust your superiors unquestioningly with utmost respect regardless of whether they deserve it or not. Forced to follow a schedule whether it’s convenient for you or not. Heck! If that isn’t prison enough, A lot of schools even have barred doors and windows! Homework is unnecessary. Have you heard someone say they have too much homework? Did you think they were being lazy or not working hard enough or procrastinating? Well, I don’t know if they were or not cause I wasn’t there, but, I doubt they were complaining without cause. The workload is rediculous, unnecessary, and downright stupid. It does not “reinforce” any learning (memorization) that took place in the classroom. If your student got an answer right on the homework or test, it probably wasn’t because of the homework! I’ll let you in on a little secret! If the student already knows something, repeating the information any number of times won’t make them know the information any more than they did before! I know right! What a crazy idea! But it’s true! I can’t tell you how many times I’ve “learned” the water cycle in ten years of school, but I can tell you that I knew the water cycle the very first time it was taught! SO WHY ARE WE GOING OVER IT TEN MORE TIMES?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?! We aren’t actually learning. We’re memorizing. I don’t even remember what we “learned” about last semester let alone last year! Even if we were truly learning, we’re learning useless stuff (as I’m sure you’ve heard a million times) but No matter how many times you’ve heard it, it’s still just as true! I’m never going to need to know how Romeo and Juliet relates to Pyramus and Thisbe! I’m never going to need to know how 10,000 year old Japanese rice farms were structured! And I’ll sure as heck never need to know how cobalt is extracted! Freaking cobalt extraction! Seriously? Even if I were to become a cobalt miner, I could learn that in the job! And if I for some reason didn’t, I could do a quick google search! But in the likely case that I will never use that information, that was a sure waste of those three days! I’m sure you’ve heard this argument at least a thousand times so I’ll stop here with this point but never you forget how true it is! Also, stop with the BS about how the useless information “teaches us how to think or react” or “how to handle social situations” because you and I can both see that, if that is the intent, it has sure as hell failed miserably. They treat us like we’re all the same. Another thing that really gets me is that no one seems to understand that everyone is different! Everyone thinks differently, is wired differently, learns differently, has different passions and strengths and weaknesses, has different interests and ignoring this fact has been shown to not work out. So… strp et! If it doesn’t work, which it clearly doesn’t, don’t use it! The current “cookie cutter” method is crap. Not only do children have different strengths and weaknesses, but they also have varying levels of intelligence and thus learning speeds. When we force kids of this variety to go at one pace, the smarter kids get bored, decide to get ahead (and somehow get in trouble for it), or lose their patience for school altogether (me) and what little growth they might have gained from our dystopian education is stunted! The slower kids are left behind, stunting what little growth they might have experienced. The average kids get to keep up, but, then they realize that it’s all pointless. This “one size fits all” method is trash and must be thrown out as such. School doesn’t care if your learning. It’s obvious in the way they prioritize things. everyone ive encountered claims that school is where you learn or it’s a place of enlightenment and higher thinking. That idea is garbage. It is painfully obvious by how much emphasis they put on grades and standardized tests that they only care about their ranking among other schools. Any learning I’ve done in the ten years of my being in school, was done on my own time (which hasn’t been much.) I questioned what causes gravity when I was in fifth grade, the teacher was still going over the water cycle. I was punished because I was curious. They still haven’t even covered the life cycle of a star and it’s sophomore year of high school! If they really wanted me to learn, they would have embraced and encouraged that kind of questioning. But instead, they shut me up and forced me to continue the face level evaluation of things that I probably would have concluded before then if I wasn’t caught up in their stupid busywork. The emphasis on standardized testing is a dead give away that they don’t care one wit what you’ve learned. They only care if you can earn them a high number on the scoreboard. The fact that they’ve even considered using standardized tests to evaluate their students worth or potential is mind blowing to me. Heck! Even the creator said that they are too crude to be used! But does anyone care? No. They just keep marching on, pretending they don’t hear our pleas for help or our rallying cries. They require us to wake up at an ungodly hour. I wake up a little after 5 to hop in some clothes, grab a quick cup of extra caffeinated coffee, and run out the door to the hell we call school. I arrive at school tired, unthinking, and unable to reason. Zombie like, i trudge through my first four classes, not learning nor able to think due to extreme exhaustion. Then, at lunch, I finally wake up, only to find myself tired and trying to recover from the first half of the day. I arrive home pretty much brain dead. I usually get about nine hours of sleep. You are probably thinking, “dude, that’s plenty of time! What are you? Insomniac or depressed or something?” To the latter of which I would say yes. But that’s beside the point. The reason why we are so tired is because getting 9 hours of sleep and getting 9 hours of sleep when your circadian rhythm tells you to, are two different things. I could dive into the science of that but I can’t right now. (You can always look it up yourself too!) We are punished for learning. Instead of encouraging us to learn from our mistakes, the school makes us feel like failures, or incompetent or stupid, when if they really were there to have us learn, they should rejoice at our mistakes. An F shouldn’t stand for failure, instead it should stand for “find another answer.” They always say that you should learn from your mistakes and then they quote famous people and say things like “I failed (insert obscenely large number here) times but that just means I found (same obscenely large number as before) ways not to make a lightbulb.” But their actions don’t support their words. would they have punished me for turning in an assignment literally six seconds late?!?!!?!?!?! No, I think not. But they did anyway! Their lack of justice. We’ve all heard stories about someone getting mugged in the stairwell or jumped on in the bathrooms, but when the kid defends themselves (especially if they succeeded in doing so) the defender is always punished instead of the actual offender. Then, someone puts a sticky note with a knock knock joke on it on a friends locker, and they get detention for a week! (True Story) needless to say, our schools need a major overhaul. No free time. Believe it or not, free time is very valuable and even essential to any child or teenagers healthy development. Let’s say school did everything right except for giving students free time, those students would still become depressed, demotivated, and unhappy to say the least. Why? Teenagers must be social! (Obviously, Not unless they don’t want to of course (duh!)) socialization is crucial for a teenagers healthy development and is essential for a child to be around allowed to play with other children! It’s a must! And it’s one of the most important things that schools overlook! In fact, most of the time, an hour of social time can be much more beneficial and educational to a teenager than if that time was used for learning! I know it’s hard to believe right? The bathroom situation. “No, jimmy, I’m teaching class right now” “But si-“ “SHUT UP JIMMY AND LET ME TEACH! YOu shoUlD hAVE gOnE tO dA BatHroOM at lunch or study hall!” “Excuse me sir!” “JIMMY I-“ “Sir, if I had to go to the bathroom during lunch or study hall, I believe I would have gone during lunch or study hall” *teacher gasps and sputters at the horrible disrespect* “Surely, sir, you don’t think I would have held it all this time, saving it just for your class did you? Besides, if you hold that policy to me, you must then hold it to everyone else in the school. Can you imagine what chaos would ensue? Can you fathom a single bathroom with 5000+ kids in there at the same time? Essentially, you would have a singularity of students, and I fail to see how that would be very helpful. Especially when they lack enough sense to not cram twenty rolls of toilet paper in the toilet, or pee in the flood drain, or write curse words on the walls in their own feces! So stop restricting our relieval of bodily fluids before someone gets a bladder infection or something! They dumb it down too much. I can’t tell you how many times we’ve gone over the water cycle. We’ve gone over WW1 +2 at least three times since the start of middle school, and they’re doing it again! This has to be at least the tenth time we’ve had to sit through a lecture on the parts of the cell, or the rock cycle. It’s like they ran out of stuff to cram down our throats, so they cram stuff they’ve already used down our throats again. I already know when and where Christopher Columbus landed. I already memorized the parts of a cell (about a thousand times! I mean, who could forget that mitochondria is the powerhouse of the cell?). If I already know it, why do we keep going over it? Perhaps they do add in more details every time they go over something, but why don’t they do that the first time??????? Is something “not school appropriate for this early an age?” Good, go over it later, but don’t redo the lesson six times!!!!!!!! Use that time to build some common sense. Teach them how use a tool correctly (there are way too many people in this world who don’t know how use a knife, and many more people who are deathly afraid of knives and anyone who uses them because they’ve heard stories of the idiots who use them incorrectly.) honestly, I think that this would be a much better way to spend that time than under-explaining something ten different times. They put all the blame on the teachers or the parents. Although, this isn’t necessarily a reason that kids don’t like school, it is also a big problem that, if fixed, would improve educational quality. Teachers are expected to teach to many different students of many different intelligence levels, interests, ways of thinking, personality, etc, and they are expected to do that job rediculously well. They have to deal with the administration screaming in their left ear, parents in their right, and the children at their throat, all with very little pay. To say that teachers have one of the most important jobs in the world would not be an overstatement, and yet they are under funded. teachers who should not be teachers are allowed to continue teaching, while the really good teachers who actually know how to do their job (who I love and respect as real jewels) are treated like trash. They do not care that they are assholes. It is quite obvious from their lack of action that they do not plan on fixing this disfuntional pile of degenerate scum we call “the Ameraican educational system.” Anytime soon (unless it involves throwing more money at the school, or standardized testing.) They are forcing an entire generation to rely on a corrupt system thus, messing up our imperfect world even more. But then again, who cares right? We’re all humans. i guess that’s what we’re best at isn’t it? Messing things up, Ruining lives, crushing dreams, destroying our future, focusing on the red herrings rather than the big picture, it’s what we do, and I guess it would appear many of us take great pride in that.
